title: Understanding Error Propagation
text: When you add two measurements, each with its own error, the total error is not simply the sum of the individual errors. Instead, you need to consider how these errors combine statistically.

title: Using the Pythagorean Theorem
text: Think of the errors as forming a right triangle, where each error is a leg of the triangle. The total error is like the hypotenuse of this triangle.

title: Calculating the Propagated Error
text: To find the propagated error when adding two measurements, use the formula: $$\sqrt{{error1}^2+{error2}^2}$$.

title: Why Use Squares?
text: Squaring the errors before adding them ensures that all errors are treated as positive contributions, regardless of their direction.

title: Final Step: Taking the Square Root
text: After summing the squares of the individual errors, take the square root to return to the original units of measurement.
